title: scots-share-stories-of-their-favourite-trees
story: THE Suffragette Oak that stands on Kelvin Way in Glasgow ndash right across the road from Hillhead Primary ndash was planted in  to commemorate women getting the vote. I noticed it one day when I went to collect my son. This would have been around .I mentioned it to a friend. She and I were in the same womens group and a friend of hers had died from breast cancer. The brass plaque beside the tree was mottled and not very well looked after.One day I saw my friend cleaning it. She told me that her friend who died had been active in the feminist economic movement and she was cleaning the plaque in her memory. The Glasgow Womens Library got involved and they campaigned for it to be Tree of the Year in .The Suffragette Oak makes me think about the forgotten history of these women: the hard work and striving that went unnoticed. Thanks to these women who went that extra mile, we now have the vote ndash we have a voice.The tree was badly damaged in a storm last year and the council had to make it safe. The bits cut off were given to Glasgow Womens Library and they are making it into things to sell to raise funds. Isnt that lovely Another special tree was one I saw at a holiday place we rented at Achnacloich, near Oban.The gardens there have this amazing redwood that looks like a gigantic hand.The reason it looks like a hand was that when it was planted a rabbit kept nibbling the bud in the middle. Every time this rabbit nibbled it, another shoot would come out the side. It was one of the first redwoods to be grown in Scotland.We were staying there with loads of kids and it was the best climbing tree in the world ndash they would get lost in it.You would be sitting outside having a cup of tea in the morning and suddenly hear a wee voice from up in the tree asking: "Whats your favourite flavour of crisps "Carole Baxter, Beechgrove Garden presenterI LOVE rowan trees. All the species are beautul. There is such a range of colourful berries and they are a hardy plant. In my garden in Aberdeenshire I have eight ieties including cashmiriana, Joseph Rock and the native rowan.I have enjoyed the rowan for its berries as long as I can remember, certainly from a young age. It is a value-for-money plant: you have the blossom and fruits, lovely foliage and great autumn colour.People perhaps arent aware of the range of species and named ieties. You dont need to have the one that has the orange-red berries you can get white, yellow and pink berries.There are some small ones as well, such as Sorbus reducta which is ideal for a rock garden. We have that one at Beechgrove as well as vilmorinii, which has pink berries with almost blueish foliage. Those were my plant choices.What is interesting is that birds tend to home in on the red and orange berries to start off with so,you have cashmiriana with its white berries, it tends to hold the berries a bit longer.This year has been particularly good for the fruits because we had a cold spring and it gradually got warmer, so we didnt have the frost and the blossoms werent damaged, which was then followed by a nice hot summer.It is nothing to do with the fact we are going to have a hard winter as people often say ndash thats an old wives tale ndash it is the fact that we have had a good season.Episodes of Beechgrove Garden are available on BBC iPlayer until November Gordon Buchanan, wildle filmmakerSCOTS pine has been my favourite tree from a young age. I grew up on Mull and I have always loved woodland. I spent a lot of time as a kid walking through the woods.One walk we did took us a mile or so out of Tobermory. When you are eight or nine, even just going a couple of miles out of town feels like you are exploring the other side of the planet.It was while out walking that I first saw a Scots pine. It was one of those classic old "granny" pines with so much character, the limbs were all twisted ndash there was one that came out at a right angle and shot skywards.This Scots pine stood among mixed birch and there was no other tree around it that looked the same. It seemed so exotic and out of place. Your eye was drawn to it.As I got older and spent time in the Cairngorms and Abernethy Forest, I learned that much of Scotland was covered in forests filled with these trees. I thought it was the most magical habitat.The tree then became a symbol for all the wildle that you find living in those forests. I have spent time filming capercaillie as well as red deer, red squirrels and pine martens among the trees.Weirdly, now I have travelled further than just a couple of miles out of town, whenever I see Scots pine, they dont look exotic to me. I have recently been working in Russia where there is mixed birch woodland and what I call "Caledonian Forest" ndash this reminder of home.My love of Scots pine is undiminished but they have gone from being a symbol of the exotic to something very familiar.A couple of years ago I was working in a mountainous region of Turkey and you could almost have been in the Cairngorms. It was very similar. I felt at home.Animal Families and Me with Gordon Buchanan is at Kirkintilloch Town Hall on November , Brunton Theatre in Musselburgh on November  and Rothes Halls in Glenrothes on November Kirsty Wark, broadcasterA TREE is a marker, something you look out for at a particular time of year. My Japanese maple in the garden, for example, you just know when the leaves are going to turn, be vivid and then flutter to the ground.The yellow-berried rowan is one of my favourite trees. I love lime trees because I think they are so vivid in the landscape.Trees represent a constancy. Planting trees is entirely altruistic because, unless they are fast-growing, you are never in your letime going to get the real benefit of them. I love the fact that parks were laid out by the Victorians ndash and even much earlier with Lancelot "Capability" Brown.After my father died, we planted a rowan where he loved to fish most, which was Kendoon Loch in Galloway. That was in . It is beside the water and Im not sure it is the most fertile place for it, but it is hanging on in there. I went to see it last week.In Celtic mythology the rowan symbolises courage and protection. That is why you will often see old houses with rowans planted in the front garden by the gate. We planted a red rowan for Dad, but I really like a yellow rowan too.I used to know the names of all the trees because I was in the Brownies. I dont know them all now. I love walking in the forest up to Glenashdale Falls and Whiting Bay on Arran, those specic spaces where you are surrounded by flora and fauna.Sir John Lister-Kaye, author and naturalistTHERE is an ash tree that is one of the biggest trees in the garden here at House of Aigas near Beauly and almost certainly the oldest ndash it is possibly  years old. It is right beside the house.Ashwas a very valuable timber throughout the th and th centuries. It was used for all sorts of things ndash implement handles, cart frames, furniture.It is a very good, close-grained hardwood. Very few ash trees ever survived more than  or  years, perhaps  years, because they were too valuable. Highlanders were not well off and it was a good way of making money.There are very few old ash trees in the Highlands. This one has survived simply because it is so close to an th-century house and I think the owners must have said many times: "Dont fell that tree, we like it". And so it survived.What is wonderful about it is that it has survived for so long and that means it has seen so much. For instance, it will have seen Bonnie Prince Charlie come through raising the clans which, of course, culminated in the Battle of Culloden.It saw the folk mourning after the loss of Culloden and it saw Cholmondeleys regiment come and camp here and then burn the tacksmans house down right beside it. The tree must have been scorched by that fire. The Frasers who were living here at the time were all murdered in May .It has witnessed some real horrors. Later, it will have witnessed the Highland Clearances, people pulling out and leaving for the New World. It will have witnessed the Victorians arriving with their grand ideas and turning the place into a sporting estate.This "loftier ash", as I call it ndash because that is what Fraxinus excelsior means ndash has seen a lot of history and for that reason alone it is a very valuable tree. In my book Song of the Rolling Earth: A Highland Odyssey, I dedicated a whole chapter to it.Let me read you a bit from it: "The ash tree has witnessed it all. I stand at its foot. Great roots have corrugated the ground around it with broad woody thongs undulating outwards in a circular plate of tangle and deep grip, roots that trail far across the lawns in every direction."It is solid, purposeful, locked in. Its trunk writhes with power. It is all heart. My fullest reach, both arms stretched, extends to less than a third of its circumference an inconsequential hug leaving me in awe of its rigid grandeur."Its bark is deeply grooved with long vertical ripples of hardness like a throng of ribbed buttresses all heading upward, shoring up its might, shedding veils of green dust at my touch."The bark fissures draw in treecreepers: those tiny mouse-like birds that dash upwards in little jerky pulses, defying gravity. Then, giving in to the earths pull, they flick down again, back to start, like a game of snakes and ladders never won."I am enthralled by this tree, rapt. Every time I stand here, I shrink it grows. I age it shrugs off such foibles and just goes on expanding into a thousand shaded alleys. What is  minutes or a week when you are  years old "Song of the Rolling Earth: A Highland Odyssey by Sir John Lister-Kaye is published by Abacus, priced pound.. Visit aigasPaul Murton, Grand Tours of Scotland presenterA TREE that I have always admired is a rowan that grows from a huge boulder. It is one that everyone will have seen as they are driving north up the A to Fort William.Just as you get to Rannoch Moor and are climbing up above Loch Tulla, there on the left-hand side of the road is a massive boulder left over from the Ice Age.There is a crack in it where, for many years, this amazing little rowan tree has been growing.It has been blasted by the elements and cant be getting many nutrients from the rock, so I dont know how it survives.There is something quite symbolic about it. I have filmed it several times for programmes over the years. It also appears in one of my favourite books, Mountaineering in Scotland by WH Murray.In fact, the first time I saw this rowan tree was in WH Murrays book when I was  or .I hitchhiked from Dunoon to Glencoe to go climbing and I remember seeing it in the flesh and thinking: "Oh, thats the one in the book".That was exciting because I felt I was on the trail of real mountaineers. Any mountaineer who had been up to Glencoe going back decades will have seen that wee tree.How did it end up there  Perhaps a crow or a raven carried a berry, dropped it and it then got stuck in a crack where there was enough nutrients for roots to grow. It must be at least  years old.Im a bit of a secret tree hugger. I planted a lot of trees at my mothers place in Argyll years ago and it is nice to admire how much they have grown. There are a couple of chestnut trees, beech trees and Scots pine.Episodes of Grand Tours of Scotlands Lochs are available on BBC iPlayer until November . The series will be repeated on BBC in Greg McHugh, actorI GREW up in Morningside in Edinburgh and at the bottom of the garden were steps down to a wood. There was a mud road with a wall and trees behind it. I loved spending time there.All the kids in my street would go down and play. It was an incredible place. I know people think of Morningside as being posh, but this wasnt a kept space. It was completely wild and overgrown. My mum would always shout as I went out the door: "Dont go near the giant hogweed!"It was this little hidden spot in the city. When I was in third year at school, I did a history project on it and learned that this was the old "poorhouse" road that had grown over.To think of the families that would have walked up and down there, the trees have been witness to all of that.We would gather conkers, climb and make rope swings among the trees and put old doors down over the stream. On fireworks night there would be a big bonfire and all the families in the street went along.One of my brothers mates stood on a wasps nest and was incredibly badly stung. Afterwards it gave spending time among the trees a new element of risk. The thing that sticks in my mind is that, while during the day it was our playground, we would never dare go down there at night.The inaugural Scottish Tree Festival organised by Discover Scottish Gardens features more than  tree-themed events and runs until December . Visit discoverscottishgardens.orgPart Two inthe Herald on Sunday: more fascinating tales of Scotlands most amazing trees

title: scotlands-25-best-loved-trees
story: THE Fortingall Yew, found growing in the churchyard of the Perthshire village which shares its name, is among the oldest trees in Europe.There is some debate about its age. Modern experts estimate the tree is between , and , years old, although others believe it could be a remnant of a post-Roman Christian site dating back , years. A figure of , to , years has also been suggested.According to folklore, Pontius Pilate ndash the Roman governor who oversaw the crucixion of Jesus ndash was born in its shade and played there as a child.One story suggests that Pilatersquos father was on a diplomatic mission to a Pictish king when news of his sonrsquos birth reached Fortingall, another that his pregnant we had been travelling with him and a third that the child was born after an illicit liaison with a local woman.More recently the legend has been credited as a hoax devised by Sir Donald Currie, a shipping magnate who bought the Glenlyon Estate in . A patron to writers such as Rudyard Kipling and Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Sir Donald is said to have invented the tale as a prank with help from his literary friends.The Dool Tree, Blairquhan Castle, AyrshireDool or dule trees were used as natural gallows for public hangings ndash and often displayed the corpse for some weeks afterwards. They were common on many estates until the mid-th century. The ancient sycamore that stands in the shadow of Blairquhan Castle is believed to be a dool tree planted in the th century during the reign of King James V of Scotland.Hawthorn Tree at Cawdor Castle and Gardens near NairnIt is said that around , William, rd Thane of Cawdor, set out to build a replacement castle on a less marshy site than its predecessor. To find a location, he followed instructions said to have come to him in a dream and loaded panniers of gold on the back of a donkey.William followed the animal as it roamed across his lands. When night fell, it rested under a tree on a higher and rockier site close to the steep-sided Allt Dearg.The castle was built on that spot with the unique quirk that it was constructed around the tree. This subsequently became a feature of part of the cellar, known since as ldquoThe Hawthorn Room.Legend has it that the tree has magical qualities which have on more than one occasion saved the castle from disaster.Modern scientic analysis has revealed that the tree died in approximately , most likely as a result of being deprived of light because the castle had been built around it. The other surprise  It is a holly tree, not a hawthorn. It still stands in the cellar to this day.Champion trees, ious locationsScotland boasts many champion trees: the largest, tallest and the exceptional. There is a Champion Tree Trail at Mount Stuart on Bute which features a Corsican pine, an evergreen coner planted around  which has grown to ft .Ardkinglas Woodland Garden at Cairndow, Argyll has an impressive collection of champion trees, including ldquothe mightiest coner in Europe, a European silver fir with an almost ftgirth.Dawyck Botanic Garden near Peebles is home to some of Britainrsquos oldest and tallest trees including a European silver fir planted in  during the reign of King Charles II. There are Douglas firs that date back to , grown from the original seed sent home by the famous botanist David Douglas.The Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh has a striking paperbark maple which is easy to identy, even in winter thanks to its eye-catching form of self-exfoliation. As the old sheaves of the copper-red bark die, they peel themselves off revealing the young, smooth bark beneath.The changeable colours of the treersquos leaves are equally dazzling. Starting out as orange in the spring, they become a pinkish-brown and then yellow, before finally turning deep green.By late autumn, the leaves have taken on a deep red hue, complementing its peeling, coppery bark. The paperbark maple was first collected in China at the turn of the th century by botanist Ernest Henry Wilson.Bicycle Tree near Brig orsquo Turk, TrossachsDating from the late th century, the so-called ldquoBicycle Tree is a sycamore reputed to have self-seeded beside the scrap heap of the village blacksmith in Brig orsquo Turk. As it grew, it absorbed ndash or swallowed up ndash several metal objects, including a bicycle and, reputedly, a shiprsquos anchor and chain.There is a fable about a young man conscripted to the First World War who left his bicycle hanging over a branch. Some say he never came back ndash orhe didfound that the tree had claimed the two-wheeled steed as its own. Today all that remains are the handlebars sticking out of the trunk.William Wallace Yew, Elderslie, RenfrewshireTwo symbolic trees once stood side-by-side: the Wallace Oak and the Wallace Yew. Now only the latter remains. Some doubt has been cast on the age, yet parish records from the s refer to it as ldquothis ancient tree. It stands near to where William Wallace is reputed to have been born in .Robertrsquos Brucersquos Yew, Loch LomondWilliam Wallace isnrsquot the only Scottish hero to have his own yew. Perched on a rocky outcrop on Loch Lomond, this ancient tree is where Robert the Bruce is said to have sheltered from his enemies in  while recounting tales of valour to keep his troopsrsquo spirits up.Wollemi pines, Inverewe Garden and Estate, Poolewe, Ross-shireInverewe boasts the worldrsquos most northerly grove of a Jurassic tree. Wollemi pine was thought to have died out two million years ago, but the species was discovered in Australia in the early s. Eight were planted at Inverewe in .Nettyrsquos Tree, Eriskay, Outer HebridesNewly crowned as Scotlandrsquos Tree of the Year  in a Woodland Trust poll, this spruce known as ldquoNettyrsquos Tree was, until recently, the only tree on Eriskay. It was planted more than  years ago by the poet, priest and land rights activist Father Allan McDonald.Netty MacDonald lived on the nearby croft and encouraged the islandrsquos children to play on the tree as their cries and laughter reminded her of her own family who had grown up and moved away to work. Netty died aged  in . Her daughter now lives on the croft and continues the tradition.Rizziorsquos Chestnut, Melville Castle Hotel, near DalkeithAccording to folklore, this Spanish chestnut tree was planted for Mary Queen of Scots by her Italian private secretary David Rizzio as a token of his love for her. The Queen responded by planting five oak trees along the drives which also survive to this day.A less public declaration may have been prudent. After rumours spread that the pair were lovers, a group of outraged Scottish nobles stabbed Rizzio  times. His brutal murder took place in front of the seven-months-pregnant queen at Holyrood Palace in .The Caledonian ForestMuch of the Highlands and what is now the Cairngorms National Park was once covered with the Caledonian Forest estimated in its heyday, around , BC, to have spanned . million hectares, about a fth of Scotlandrsquos land mass.By , BC, however, as the climate became wetter and windier, the forest was reduced signicantly. It continued to shrink in size from then onwards largely due to human intervention.Today the Caledonian Forest exists in  remnants. The Scots pine trees found here are directly descended from the native pinewoods that grew around , BC and once formed the westernmost outpost of the Boreal Forest in Europe.Beneath the vast forest canopy, the likes of wild boar, lynx, brown bears and grey wolves ndash now extinct in the wild in Scotland ndash roamed.The Caledonian Forest is still home to some of the rarest wildle in the British Isles, including mountain hare, pine marten, red squirrel, Scottish wildcats, capercaillie, crested tit and Scottish crossbill.It was revealed last month that a poundm Endangered Landscapes Programme has selected the Caledonian Forest to be the focus of a key restoration project ndash along with seven other major regeneration schemes ndash to restore Europersquos most threatened environments.Mallochrsquos Oak, Strathallan Castle, PerthshireThere is a dark history tied to the Mallochrsquos Oak in the grounds of Strathallan Castle. It is said that during a famine the local miller, Malloch, hoarded flour and grain instead of distributing it to the starving locals. He was strung up from this tree as punishment.Copper beech tree, Drummond Castle Gardens, PerthshireThe formal terraced gardens include a copper beech tree planted by Queen Victoria to commemorate her visit in .The Camperdown Elm, Camperdown Park, DundeeA contorted weeping elm discovered in woods near Dundee in , it is thought to have been re-planted near what was then the Earl of Camperdownrsquos new mansion house and is now within the cityrsquos Camperdown Park.Flodden Tree, The Hirsel Estate near Coldstream, BerwickshireThis sycamore on the Hirsel Estate in the Borders is believed to have been planted in tribute to the Scottish dead at the Battle of Flodden in .Napoleonrsquos Tree, Ecclefechan, DumfriesshireDuring his final days on the Atlantic island of St Helena, Napoleon Bonaparte befriended British Army surgeon Archibald Arnott. Two days before he died, Napoleon gave instructions that no British doctor except Arnott should touch him.A weeping willow tree was Napoleonrsquos favourite spot for contemplation on the island and he asked to be buried under its shade. This wish was fulfilled when he died in  and Napoleon was interred there until being repatriated to France almost  years later.Arnott took a cutting from the tree, planting it on hishome to Ecclefechan, where it still grows in the grounds of the Kirkconnel Hall Hotel.The ldquoFilo Pastry Tree, Logan Botanic Gardens near StranraerThis impressive specimen of Polylepis australis ndash the largest of its kind in the UK ndash got its nickname from a Stranraer Academy pupil who compared the flaky bark to the filo pastry on a spring roll. Originating from South America, its peeling bark traps air to keep the tree warm at night.Redwood Avenue, Benmore Botanic Garden, ArgyllVisitors enter the gardens through the majestic Redwood Avenue which was planted in , a time when the American Civil War was at its height and Queen Victoria was on the throne. These towering Sequoiadendron giganteum are now around  metres high.Birnam Oak and Birnam Sycamore, PerthshireThe Birnam Oak and its neighbour the Birnam Sycamore are thought to be the sole surviving trees of the great forest that once straddled the banks of the River Tay. This is immortalised in Shakespearersquos Macbeth as the Birnam Wood.The ldquoBig Tree, Kirkwall, OrkneyTo be fair, the ldquoBig Tree is not actually that lofty. Rather, this -year-old sycamore is much beloved among Orcadians due to its prominent position on Kirkwallrsquos main street making it a popular meeting spot. It was voted Scotlandrsquos Tree of the Year .The giants of Reelig Glen, InvernessReelig Glen boasts some of Britainrsquos tallest trees: a Douglas fir that, when measured in , came in at .fta larch measuring .fta .ft-highNorway spruce and a lime tree which stands at .ft . The Dughall Mor ndash the big dark stranger ndash a Douglas fir planted in  also grows there.Queen Maryrsquos Thorn, St Andrews UniversityA hawthorn said to have been planted by Mary, Queen of Scots in the s grows in the grounds of St Maryrsquos College at St Andrews University. Interestingly, Moray House Garden at Edinburgh University once had its own Queen Maryrsquos Thorn, believed to have been lost in the mid-th century as the teacher training college expanded.Stevensonrsquos Yew, EdinburghThe yew was a favourite play spot for Robert Louis Stevenson - author of Treasure Island, Kidnapped and the Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde - as a child visiting his grandfather in the Colinton area of Edinburgh. It is said the marks of a swing are still visible on its branches.Robert Kirkrsquos Fairy Tree, AberfoyleReverend Robert Kirk wrote the book The Secret Commonwealth of Elves, Fauns And Fairies in filled with stories about those who claimed to have had contact with these mythical beings, including Kirk himself.He believed that the Doon Hill in Aberfoyle was a gateway to the world of the fairies. Kirk died in  after collapsing while visiting the hill at night. It is likely he suffered a heart attack, yet rumours swirled among local people that he been carried away by the fairies for revealing their secrets.Doon Hill is also known as ldquoFairy Knowe or ldquoDun Sithean and according to legend Kirkrsquos soul is still trapped inside a lone Scots pine. Today, people hang ribbons and messages around the trees in this area to ward off illness and bad luck or commemorate a loved one.Beech Avenue, Achnacarry, Inverness-shireThe story goes that Donald ldquoThe Gentle Lochiel Cameron heard about the arrival in Scotland of Charles Edward Stuart ndash Bonnie Prince Charlie ndash while planting this avenue of beech trees on his estate at Achnacarry, just prior to the Jacobite rising of .The inaugural Scottish Tree Festival organised by Discover Scottish Gardens features more than  tree-themed events and runs until December . Visit discoverscottishgardens.org

title: scotlands-most-senior-trade-union-figure-faces-internal-unrest-over-outside-earnings
story: A private meeting of the Scottish Trades Union Congresslast week included a discussion on general secretary Grahame Smith, who is believed to have boosted his pay packet by around pound, for sitting on Government-linked boards.The STUCrsquos governing body is now reviewing its procedures for membership of external bodies.The Herald on Sunday contacted some of the STUCrsquos largest affiliated unions about the controversy, but many did not provide a comment.However, a spokesperson for the GMB Scotland union, which is a key part of the STUC, said: "On numerous occasions we have raised our concerns about transparency and accountability in the running of the STUC. This is to defend the jobs and conditions of the staff we represent in the STUC and to ensure the organisations future ability to campaign effectively on behalf of all its affiliate members. We will continue to address those concerns through the internal processes of the STUC."As the umbrella body for nearly  affiliated trade unions, the STUC represents around , workers and acts as the voice of organised labour north of the border.However, critics have questioned the STUCrsquos independence under Mr Smithrsquos leadership after it emerged the body received over % of its funding from the SNP Government last year.Mr Smith, who became general secretary in , has also faced sniping from within the trade union world over the way he has topped up an STUC remuneration package thought to be close to pound,.As a board member of jobs quango Scottish Enterprise between  and , Mr Smith is believed to have received up to pound, in fees.He currently has three additional posts which attract payment. As a board member of Skills Development Scotland he is entitled to between pound, and pound, a year and qualies for a pound, a year salary bump as a board member of the Scottish Qualications Authority. He can also receive a daily rate as a member of the Enterprise and Skills Enterprise Board.Mr Smith was also briefly the interim chair of the Glasgow Colleges Regional Board, for which he received pound,, but he did not not receive any remuneration for his time on the UK Commission on Employment and Skills.The payments issue was raised last week at a meeting of the STUCrsquos general council, which is comprised of union representatives.At one point, staff left the room so that affiliates could discuss matters in private, a session that lasted around two hours.It is understood unhappiness was expressed about the money Mr Smith had received since  for sitting on boards, the transparency of appointments, as well as the lack of an in-house register of interest.Others at the meeting said they were not singling out any one inidual as previous general secretaries had also sat on external boards.However, a trade union source said Mr Smith was becoming ldquomarginalised.The row also comes amid a debate within the trade union movement over male trade unionists hogging multiple posts.In a statement to this newspaper, STUC President Lynn Henderson said:ldquoThe STUC engagement with a range of public bodies is reported every year in the General Council report to our Annual Congress. The General Council is currently reviewing our processes and procedures. We are considering how these can be improved to ensure that the considerable influence the trade union movement has on such bodies and on public policy can be further enhanced.ldquoIn serving on public bodies, the General Secretary is following the same practice as his predecessors. I believe that in doing so, the General Secretary is always focused on advancing the interests of unions and working people. Grahame has served as General Secretary for  years and is widely respected throughout the trade union movement and wider civil society. During that period the STUC has continued to exert considerable influence over the direction of economic and social policy in Scotland.

title: snp-run-glasgow-council-snubs-swinney-by-removing-his-name-from-teacher-pay-letter
story: The Deputy First Minister initially co-signed the draft communication to teachers, but Glasgow city council snubbed him and put it out from their own education convener.Labour MSP Iain Gray said: "With John Swinney becoming increasingly unpopular with teachers, it is no surprise that SNP-run Glasgow City Council deleted his signature from the letter.Mr Swinney is embroiled in a bitter row with the trade unions over their demand for teachers pay to be increased by %.Council umbrella group COSLA, with the support of the Scottish Government, has offered % and strike action is on the horizon.The Government has also suggested that an overhaul of the main grade scale, coupled with the % rise, would result in some teachers getting a boost in excess of %.However, the disagreement was aggravated after the Government and COSLA agreed to go over the heads of the unions by sending a ldquojoint communication directly to teachers about the offer.The Education Secretary wanted teachers to hear his side of the pay proposal before they voted in a consultative ballot.The draft letter was co-signed by Mr Swinney and Tory councillor Gail Macgregor, who is COSLArsquos resources spokesperson, and stated:ldquoWe firmly believe that this is a fair offer which demonstrates that both Local Government and the Scottish Government value the teaching profession. We are disappointed that it has been rejected by the teacher unions.ldquoThe teacher unionsrsquo claim for % in a single year cannot be achieved. It is simply unaffordable, and the unions have been told this since their claim was submitted at the start of the year.They also said the pay offer and the grading restructuring amounted to a poundm investment in teachers.However, when teachers in Glasgow received the letter by email, the names of Mr Swinney and Ms Macgregor had vanished. The signature of SNP councillor Chris Cunningham, who is the convener for Education, Skills  Early Years, appeared instead.The wording was the same as the initial draft put together by COSLA and the Government, apart from an extra paragraph at the beginning:ldquoCOSLA Leaders agreed that a joint letter from the Scottish Government and COSLA should be prepared and sent out to teachers explaining the pay offer to them.ldquoThe information below is from the Scottish Government and COSLA which talks to the offer on the table and I would be gratefulyou could share it with teachers in your school.Glasgow was a Labour bastion at a local authority level for decades, but the SNP won control of the council for the first time last year.Around , teachers, many of whom are based in Glasgow, protested against Mr Swinney over the pay standoff at a rally in the city recently.Placards included lsquoSwinney is a ninny and lsquoEbenezer Swinneyrsquo, which an education source said was an indication of the hostility to the SNP heavyweight by teachers.A Council spokeswoman said: ldquoOur City Convener for Education, Skills  Early Years, Councillor Chris Cunningham has sent a letter to schools which includes information from the Scottish Government and Cosla on the teachers pay award proposal.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has worked with COSLA to put in place the best teacher pay deal in the UK for -.It is important that the component parts of the deal are explained in detail so that teachers have a full understanding of the proposals on the table.

title: new-series-from-sir-david-attenborough-to-start-on-bbc-one
story: Each episode of Dynasties follows a dferent animal ndashthe chimpanzee, emperor penguins, hunting dogs, lions and tigers.The naturalist has said he wason the ldquoedge of his seat watching footage from the series, which was filmed all over the world.He said: ldquoDynasties came from an idea that it would be interesting to follow a particular group of animals which scientists watching them had thought was going to have some kind of revolution.ldquoMaybe lions taking over a dferent pride, maybe chimpanzees having a competition for leadership.ldquoThen the producer made a very bold statement: we will put a crew, a film crew, and we will film exactly what happened, and we donrsquot know whether itrsquoll be a triumph, we donrsquot know whether itrsquoll be a tragedy. But wersquoll show you the truth.ldquoI only saw it when the films were finally edited and came back. And they didnrsquot tell me what was going to happen and I was on the edge of my seat too because in the most remarkable way you identy with some of these characters.A story of power, politics and the fight for survival. Wersquove been waiting a whole year to hear Sir David Attenboroughrsquos narration again. Yoursquoll want sound on! # #Dynastiespic NqrTPdmdash BBC OneNovember , Describing the first episode of the series, he said: ldquoTherersquos an aged old chimpanzee, which we used the names which the scientists themselves used who are watching it, and they called this chimpanzee, I must say a bit to my embarrassment, they called it David.ldquoAnyway he was this rather alarming alpha male who threw his weight around a bit but was obviously coming to the end of his rule, and I didnrsquot know what was going to happen, they hadnrsquot told me.ldquoAnd I watched the finished film with my eyes wide open because it was an amazing and very involving drama.ldquoAnd thatrsquos the benefit of following these animals in this kind of way, that you become very, very involved.Another episode in the series follows a group of emperor penguins in the Antarctic, and Sir David said: ldquoThe emperor penguin programme is slightly dferent from all the rest because itrsquos not about one particular emperor penguin or family, and indeed you couldnrsquot tell because all emperor penguins look exactly the same.ldquoThe only way they can survive in the heart of the Antarctic isthe males endure the winter with their eggs sitting on their feet, throughout the hideous blizzards they sit there in a huddle and the blizzard comes in.ldquoAnd after a bit the chap, the males in the front they canrsquot survive any longer unless they blow this for a game of marbles and they walk around the side and they come round the back.ldquoBut this is filmed in such detail and with such skill and in such circumstances that well, you may think yoursquove seen emperor penguins, but until yoursquove seen this programme you really havenrsquot.Sir David has also said the series highlights the problem of how to allow animals enough space as the human population encroaches on their habitats.He said: ldquoAnimals also deserve a space on this planet. We are latecomers and the animals were there before us. And maybe we should be taking care of them, making allowance for them, giving them space.Dynasties begins on BBC One at .pm.

title: armistice-centenary-silences-observed-in-australia-and-new-zealand
story: Tens of thousands of Australians and New Zealanders gave their lives in the First World War.Thousands gathered for a national service of remembrance at the Australian War Memorial in Canberra, where Prime Minister Scott Morrison led a minutersquos silence at am .In Sydney, crowds gathered at the Anzac Memorial, an extension of which was unveiled by the Duke of Sussex during his recent trip with Meghan, while there was also a service at the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne.The Commemorative Address is being delivered by The Honourable Scott Morrison, Prime Minister of Australia. #HonourTheirSpirit #RemembranceDay pic XWVOlsmevLmdash Aust War MemorialNovember , Some , Australians served overseas during the First World War, the vast majority of whom fought on the Western Front alongside British soldiers and their allies.Over , died in the conflict, more than two-thirds on the battlefields of Europe.Over three thousand people joined in remembrance and hope at the #Armistice National Ceremony at #Pukeahu in #Wellington, marking the centenary of the th hour of the th day of the th month, , when war gave way to peace https:t.co niDbsbLs pic FFdxZNZmdash WW New ZealandNovember , Earlier, large crowds attended the Pukeahu National War Memorial Park in Wellington for New Zealandrsquos main remembrance ceremony, where a minutersquos silence was observed at am .Nearly , served in New Zealand units overseas, with around a fth never ing home.

title: theresa-may-faces-struggle-to-keep-brexit-plans-on-track-amid-tory-tensions
story: With the shock resignation of pro-Europe transport minister Jo Johnson continuing to cause ructions in Tory ranks, the Prime Minister is running out of time to seal an EU exit deal.Hope of getting the Cabinet to sign off on Brexit deal proposals this week appeared to be rapidly receding as it was reported the EU had rejected UK plans for an independent arbitration clause that could allow the UK to quit a backstop deal on the Northern Ireland border.With both pro and anti-withdrawal Tories becoming more vocal in their opposition to Mrs Mayrsquos stance, arch-Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg called on the PM to change tack.He urged Mrs May to end the deadlock by paying the EU pound billion to secure a ldquono deal plus arrangement with the bloc after withdrawal.Writing in the Mail on Sunday, Mr Rees-Mogg, who heads the influential European Research Group of  Tory MPs, suggested offering the financial deal to Brussels in order toldquomake our departure as amicable as possible.Previously critical of the pound billion orce bill the UK is set to pay the EU, Mr Rees-Mogg wrote: ldquoIt is time for convinced Brexiteers like me to compromise.ldquoSo, at this late hour in the negotiations, we would like to make a new, generous offer to break the deadlock, to achieve a lsquoNo Deal Plusrsquo.ldquoIt would cost us money but it would finally dispel the lsquocrash outrsquo Project Fear nightmare scenarios.A Government source told the Press Association: ldquoThe end part of negotiations were always going to be tough.ldquoThere are a number of issues that need to be worked through on the Northern Ireland backstop and these are the most dficult.ldquoThey include ensuring that,it is ever needed, it is not permanent and there is a mechanism to ensure the UK could not be held in the arrangement indefinitely.Well done to @JoJohnsonUK on standing up for what he believes in. He was a fantastic Minister to work with whilst we were at the DfE. Itrsquos a sad loss for Gvt, but Brexit is above party politics. https:t.co icoTQDFvmdash Justine GreeningNovember , Former Cabinet minister Justine Greening, who shares Mr Johnsonrsquos view that a fresh referendum is needed, called on Tories to oppose the PMrsquos Chequers proposals.She told The Observer: ldquoThe parliamentary deadlock has been clear for some time. Itrsquos crucial now for Parliament to vote down this plan, because it is the biggest giveaway of sovereignty in modern times.The view was echoed by Brexiteer Tory MP Andrew Bridgen who told a meeting of the Bruges Group: ldquoIf we canrsquot chuck Chequers then itrsquos time to chuck the Prime Minister.Tory Brexiteer Steve Baker and DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson wrote in The Sunday : ldquoIf the Government makes the historic mistake of prioritising placating the EU over establishing an independent and whole UK, then, regrettably, we must vote against the deal.Brexiteers have insisted that the UK should not get involved with a potentially permanent backstop customs union agreement with the EU as the price of avoiding a hard border in Northern Ireland.

title: silhouettes-of-tommies-projected-on-to-famous-uk-landmarks
story: The Tommies illuminated Marble Arch, Tate Modern, HMS Belfast, Warwick Castle, the Angel of the North, the Tyne Bridge, Titanic Belfast, Cardf Castle and Edinburgh Castle.The silhouettes have appeared all over the UK since the campaign launched in February, commemorating the British and Commonwealth troops who died in the First World War whilst also raising funds for military charities.General the Lord Dannatt, patron of There But Not There and former chief of the general staff, said: ldquoAs we reach  years since the Armistice, it is vital that we reflect on the sacrice made by an entire generation of servicemen and women.ldquoThese wonderful landmarks coming together provide a remarkable representation of the nation doing exactly just that.ldquoWe have been incredibly moved by the overwhelming public support that we have received across the country, which has led to more than pound million raised for military and mental health charities.ldquoHowever, our journey doesnrsquot stop here we need the publicrsquos backing more than ever in raising funds to support our veterans in crisis.ldquoMental health remains a crucial issue and we hope people will see these poignant silhouettes and be inspired to buy their own Tommy to both remember the fallen and to help those that continue to struggle today.

story: Analysis of the Scottish labour market indicates that, people are now earning less than the living wage of pound. per hour.It represents an increase of , on the , people cited in the report for .The hourly living wage rate for adults in  was set at pound..The study suggests that the health and education sectors have seen the largest increase in the number of people earning less than the living wage.In health and social work services, employees were earning less than the living wage in  ndash an increase of% on the  people in .In education,  people were recorded as earning under the living wage ndash the numberincreased by % to  people in .In the accommodation and food services sector, were earning less than the living wage in . The SNP should hang its head in shame.ldquoThose in the health and education sectors perform valuable work ndash they deserve much better than poverty pay.ldquoUnder Labour work will pay, with a pound per hour real living wage, a ban on zero-hours contracts and better rights with more security at work.ldquoUnder the broken economy of the SNP and the Tories, more and more people are on poverty pay in Scotland this year, than last ndash including some of the most valued workers in society.ldquoLabour governments at Holyrood and Westminster have a plan to end poverty pay, including introducing a real living wage of pound an hour and an industrial strategy that will deliver high-wage, high-skill jobs across Scotland.Business Minister Jamie Hepburn said: ldquoDespite the UK Governmentrsquos austerity agenda, Scotland has the highest proportion of employees being paid at least the real Living Wage of all four UK nations. This will focus on grant recipients paying the real Living Wage, not using exploitative zero hours contracts and meeting requirements to publish gender pay gap data.ldquoThe First Minister has also set out out a lsquoFair Work Firstrsquo agenda to extend Fair Work criteria to as many funding streams, business support grants and public contracts as we can by the end of this Parliament.ldquoThis means investment in skills and training no exploitative zero hours contracts action on gender pay genuine workforce engagement, including with trade unions and payment of the real Living Wage.ldquoThe STUC have welcomed this commitment and we will continue to work with them to maximise the impact of this agenda for workers across Scotland.With low pay one of the main drivers of in-work poverty, itrsquos vital that employers who can pay the real Living Wage do so

title: why-we-should-all-commemorate-armistice-day-2018
story: Mark Bibbey, Poppyscotland chief executive, said: ldquoAt am this morning, the nation will stand in silent reflection as we mark Remembrance Sunday. Of course, today has added signicance as it is exactly  years since the signing of the Armistice that brought the First World War to an end.ldquoIt was a conflict which saw almost one million British and Commonwealth soldiers lose their lives many more seriously damaged by physical or mental trauma and which changed our society and how we live our lives in so many ways.ldquoAs we pass such a signicant milestone some have questioned the continued relevance of the annual act of Remembrance. However, I believe that Remembrance remains relevant today and into the future for two important reasons.ldquoFirstly, becausewe do not continue to acknowledge the lessons of the past then we risk repeating them in the future and, secondly, because the men and women of our Armed Forces continue to selflessly put themselves in harmrsquos way in order to defend our freedoms which so many have paid the ultimate price to preserve.ldquoWe at Poppyscotland believe that no-one should be disadvantaged by their time in the service and that is why our work in providing those in our Armed Forces community with le-changing support remains so vitally important today.ldquoIt is for these reasons that I think that Armistice Day, Remembrance Sunday and the Scottish Poppy Appeal must and will retain the upmost relevance well beyond this yearrsquos centenary.Victoria Wallace, director general of Commonwealth War Graves Commission, said: ldquoWe are proud to be s of the final resting places of the Commonwealth men and women who died in the two world wars, as well as commemorating the thousands with no known grave.ldquoWe hope everyone will take a moment at this special centenary to find their local CWGC site, and make a small pilgrimage to honour the men and women who gave their all. With war graves or memorials in almost every town and village in the UK and more than  countries and territories, we hope to see more people than ever on Remembrance Sunday.Erskine chief executive Wing Commander Ian Cumming MBE said: ldquoArmistice Day is a signicant and poignant event for everyone at Erskine, but for our veterans in particular. We remember those who made the ultimate sacrice, during a century of conflicts from the First World War to the present day.ldquoWe support our veteran residents who served during the Second World War, as they each reflect inidually on what they saw and the friends they lost. And, of course, Erskine staff and beneficiaries who saw fighting and peacekeeping in more recent conflicts also come together to support each other. We reflect on what we have learned about the devastating physical and psychological effects of war on iniduals and families. Most importantly at this time of year, Erskine remembers those who gave their lives, so that we might live in freedom. We pledge to honour their memory by caring for those heroes who did come home.Justine Baynes, director at SSAFA, the Armed Forces charity, said: ldquoSSAFA, the Armed Forces charity, was the only national, tri-service charity around during World War One. At the outbreak of the war, SSAFA was called upon by the Government to look after the families left behind.ldquoTo mark the centenary of the Armistice, SSAFA is encouraging families to keep our nationrsquos history alive, by sharing their stories of World War One, so they will never be forgotten.ldquoThe further we move away from the conflict, the more important it becomes to keep the stories of bravery and courage alive, and commemorate those who gave up their lives for our country.ldquoThis Sunday, take a moment to remember those who lost their lives during the First World War and in each conflict ever since.Sue Freeth, chief executive of Combat Stress, the UKrsquos leading charity for veteransrsquo mental health, said: ldquoI will be laying a wreath at the Cenotaph on Remembrance Sunday. Irsquom sure it will be a very moving experience. I will be extremely proud to march alongside veterans and colleagues from Combat Stress. Itrsquos important to remember not only those servicemen and women we have lost but also those whofrom conflicts needing support, care and treatment.

title: sunnyside-up-the-coolest-brunches-in-scotland
story: . Partick Duck ClubPartick, GlasgowThe coolest place to have brunch these days isnrsquot Finnieston, but Partick, where there is a restaurant that makes all other brunches look unimaginative. You may have your ideas about what brunch fodder is, but the Partick Duck Club takes it to a new dimension with its Duck Leg and Nduja hash or their Orkney Crab  Poached Duck Egg on Toast with Avocado and Cregraveme Fraiche. Plus,yoursquore in the mood, and starting off the day with a party, or the hair of a dog, it delivers an excellent Bloody Mary or a Gin Mary. Itrsquos relaxed, informal, cosy ndash but as Joanna Blythman, who gave the food . , has put it, ldquothe cooking is seriously polished. They even open at am for breakfast ndash though breakfast, of course, is too small a concept to apply to anything served at Partick Duck Club.. Cafeacute GandolfiMerchant City, GlasgowIt was a trendsetter back in the day ndash now itrsquos an irresistible classic, with its rustic wooden chairs and encyclopedic menu. Forget shakshuka and brunch in timeless style from a menu that goes on and on, but which includes eggs cocotte, Aberdeen Smoked Haddie and dishes with Stornoway black pudding. Itrsquos said that Cafeacute Gandolfi, which opened in , imported the cityrsquos first cappuccino machine.. ToastLeith, EdinburghToast describes itself as a wine cafeacute, soreally good natural or biodynamic wine is what you want with your lateish brunch, then herersquos the place to head. ldquoA cool and comfortable hub for all things wine and coffee related, is how Zak Han its founder describes it. Take up a spot by the window looking out over the Shore and try their shakshuka or huevos rancheros, before finishing off with one of their cakes which look untouchably beautul, yet taste ine. Andthe tables are all booked, remember the Shore, like all trendy spots, is spoiled for choice ndash you only need to walk a few steps to find another top brunch provider.. Singl-endGarnethill and Merchant City, GlasgowNo longer is there just a single Singl-end. There are now two ndash andyour idea of a heavenly brunch involves some seriously good bread, then look no further than one of these joints. They even have bread ldquomenus, which include the likes of sourdough, Altamura, sweet potato and almond, bread of the day and others. But itrsquos not all about the bakes ndash here, they also make their own pork and fennel bangers, serving them with cannellini beans and chilli, and a heavenly vegan breakfast that includes sweet potato rounds and avocado and chilli smash. Plus, their boho vibe and leather armchairs make them the perfect place to relax. One Glasgow food blogger described it as ldquoa little slice of chilled out heaven on a Sunday morning". Open at am on Sundays.. Bird And BearCity Centre, DundeeThe home of the hip-hop brunch. Yes, that is an official thing. On both Saturdays and Sundays from am-pm, Bird And Bear gives brunch the music vibe it deserves. This is the place for for those who like a chilled, no-rush Sunday of listening to some old-school sounds, while chowing down on dishes from a menu that includes such highlights as coconut and quinoa pancakes, baked pimento eggs and the steak breakfast. You can even revive with an alcoholic milkshake. Plus the deacutecor, with its hammered copper, birdcages and palm wallpaper, is a paradise of cool.. The Tatha Bar And KitchenDundee WaterfrontYes, brunch is about the food, but itrsquos also the location, the view, being transported ndash and Tatha Bar And Kitchen, the VArsquos brunch venue, with its huge glass windows and balcony over the Tay certainly works those factors. Here, you can combine a tour of the iconic museum with a stop-off for an open breakfast burrito or a smoked Perthshire salmon royal. Chef Brian Canale runs a scratch kitchen which means everything is made fresh each morning. Be warned, though, the VA is still mobbed at the weekends, and yoursquore best advised to book.. Mountain CafeacuteAviemore, CairngormsThere are times when, alluring as an early start on the mountain is, what you crave is a good, big lazy brunch. For those days there is always the Mountain Cafeacute, which opens for breakfast at .am and keeps on serving it throughout the day. Owner-chef Kirsten Gilmour, who describes herself as ldquoa Kiwi in the Cairngorms, brings her antipodean style to the dishes. Itrsquos hard to look further than the All Day Brekki or the Veg Brekkie, delivering everything you could want on a plate. As might be expected, this is about hearty food ndash the kind of breakfast that might keep you going as you tackle the great outdoors.. Sanddollar CafeacuteBeach front, AberdeenWhat better way to spend a Sunday morning than a bracing walk along the sands followed by a pile of pancakes  Beach and brunch are a match made in heaven, and this cafeacute on the esplanade, with a wide breakfast menu, is a huge draw for families who want to chill and eat. When the sun is shining you can sit out on wooden tables. Or, when the wind gets up, cosy up inside and enjoy its bright, airy atmosphere. Opens at .am.. Cafe SiaBroadford, SkyeIn a cosy white bungalow at the foot of the Red Cuillin hills is a cafeacute that does it all ndash brunch, pizza, seafood, but most of all the best coffee, so they claim, on the island. Sia means six, and thatrsquos the number of menu options it offers for brunch, including the all-day breakfast, eggs florentine or benedict, pancakes and the Siabatta, a ciabatta with breakfast filling. Its barista, Craig, sources coffee beans and small batch roasts them in the ldquowee red Samiac drum. Open from .am.. Mhor Balquhidder, The TrossachsSometimes a brunch is just what you need to interrupt a journey north or south through the mountains, or as a reviving feast the day after some serious hill-walking. Mhor , one of the sister venues to fine-dining star Monachyle Mhor is there for those moments. Itrsquos a motel, restaurant, bar and cafeacute and its breakfasts, served from am until .am, are beyond moreish ndash though itrsquos hard to imagine anyone would be wanting any more after theyrsquove eaten a ldquobig breakfast that includes all the regulars plus Stornoway black pudding, haggis and potato scone.. Fairmont HotelSt Andrews, FeYou could call this a brunch, but really its more of a branquet, including everything from a carvery to an extraordinary patisserie selection. The word branquet isnt in common use just yet, but really it should be, so we all know the dference between a regular brunch and the feast thats being provided here. The hotel ran its International Brunches over the summer, but they were so popular they were extended all the way to Christmas. All of this in the glamour of the hotelrsquos Atrium under the glow of their George Singer lighting installation. Priced at pound. per adult and pound per child, from pm-pm.. Fruin FarmLoch Lomond National ParkWhat could be a better way of brunching with kids than to do it on a farm  Followed by a wander round the farmyard, some pond dipping or a llama trek, and a gaze at the views down the glen  If you want to know precisely where every bit of your brunch has come from ndash and maybe see something like it wandering around outside ndash then this is the place to eat. Everything, they say, has been raised and slaughtered in the UK, none of it intensively farmed not Puddledub bacon, Katy Rodgers natural yogurt, Stornoway black pudding. Breakfast here finishes at .am, so yoursquore looking at an early start ndash but chances are the kids have had you up since dawn anyway., Birnam brasserieGleneagles, AuchterarderBrunch at the Birnam Brasserie at Gleneagles is so special it only happens on the first Sunday of the month ndash which tells you a little about just how swanky it is. This is destination brunching at its most decadent, with live jazz playing the background, a Bellini station and an ice-cream cart, and deacutecor that evokes a Grand Parisian cafe. All the brunch classics are there, but also the croques monsieur, the steak and eggs with frites and a self-serve cold bar brimming with shellfish, seafood, charcuterie, cheese and salads. .-.pm, prices from pound per adult and pound per child. Yes, its another branquet ndash beyond indulgence.. The Glad Cafeacute, Southside, GlasgowWhere southside creative types go not only to brunch, but hang out, listen to music, talk about art, watch film, write a few poems or log on to their wi. Glad Cafeacute also happens to offer one of the best vegan and vegetarian brunches in Glasgow, courtesy of Hen Of The Woods ndash also the team behind The Hug And Pint ndash on both Saturdays and Sundays, am until pm. Middle Eastern flavours, Asian influences, sourdough bread from social enterprise, the Freedom Bakery. Think dishes like poached eggs with salted yoghurt and chilli brown butter tofu chettinad, washed down with a cup of Dear Green Coffee and a good dollop of social conscience.. The PantryStockbridge, EdinburghWhen the Pantry launched in  it became the definition of brunch in Edinburgh, leading the way on what you can do with an egg, a pancake or a waffle. The Sunday Times said their eggrsquos benedict was ldquoreason alone to come to Edinburgh. It still remains hard to beat and repeatedly pops up on lists of best brunches and breakfasts in the UK. Run by husband-and-we team, Chris and Charlotte Thompson, and described as an urban farm shop ndash it serves locally-sourced produce. Itrsquos also nestled in an elegant spot in the New Town, right on Royal Circus. Open daily for brunch from am to pm.. VestaWest End, EdinburghThe indulgent brunch with a conscience. Social Bitersquos Home has been relaunched, refurbished and rethought as something new and fresh, and on Sundays its offering its Bubbles and Brunch. The restaurant still works on the same principle ndash homeless people train and work there and customers are encouraged to ldquopay forward meals for the homeless. Itrsquos a quality brunch too ndash offering buttermilk pancakes, avocado on toast with salsa and watercress or baked eggs with cheddar, spinach, tomatoes and black beans, as well as some fizz on the side.. GnomSouthside, GlasgowBreakfast bao, or steamed Asian buns, are one of the chief foodie draws of this Southside brunch venue, and they are good ndash filled with crispy pork belly or mushrooms, gochujang ketchup and eggs. And who could not be tempted by their French toast ice cream sandwiches  Head there for a blether over brunch by its big, bright windows. Itrsquos hipster central, but irresistible.. The Gardenerrsquos CottageCalton Hill, EdinburghFor a brunch thatrsquos about the locally-sourced greens, herbs and heritage carrots as well as the eggs, sausages and kippers, this intimate restaurant in a converted cottage in the gardens at the foot of Calton Hill is the go-to destination. Itrsquos not, as Joanna Blythman, once commented without its middle-class ldquoaffectation ndash but its brunch really does feel fresh from the garden. If, however, the big foodie love affair in your le is bread ndash and you also like your brunch a bit more casual and Scandi ndash then therersquos sister cafeacute Quay Commons in Leith. Brioche heaven.

title: the-harsh-armistice-terms
story: These included: The cessation of hostilities within six hours. Evacuation of France, Belgium, Luxembourg, and Alsace-Lorraine within  days, the sick and wounded left behind for Allies to care for. The withdrawal of German forces to behind the Rhine and Allied occupation of the Rhineland. The preservation of infrastructure. Surrender of mateacuteriel: , artillery pieces, , machine guns, , minenwerfers , , aircraft , , railway locomotives, , railcars and , trucks. Immediate release of all Allied prisoners of war, without reciprocity. All minefields on land and sea to be identied. Eventual reparations. However, the relaxation of the naval blockade of Germany which had brought widespread starvation and death was not agreed to.Following the Armistice the occupation of the Rhineland took place. The occupying armies consisted of American, Belgian, British, and French forces.

title: events-held-across-the-uk-and-around-the-world-to-commemorate-armistice-day-centenary
story: The festival commemorated all those who have lost their lives in conflicts and marked  years since the First World War ended.The Queen was joined by the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.A series of events will take place across the UK today to mark  years since the end of the First World War.The Prince of Wales will once again lead the nation in honouring the countrys war dead during the national service of remembrance.The Queen has asked Charles to lay a wreath at the Cenotaph in Whitehall on her behalf ndash the second successive year he will perform the duty. The Queen will watch from the balcony of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office building, as she did last year.After Charles has laid a wreath, other floral tributes will be left by members of the royal family, senior figures from the government, including Prime Minister Theresa May, and opposition party leaders and other figures from national le.The SNPrsquos Westminster leader, Ian Blackford MP, will lay a wreath on behalf of the SNP and Plaid Cymru that will include the words ldquoLest we forget in English, Gaelic and Welsh.Blackford said: ldquoI am honoured to be able to attend the ceremony today at the Cenotaph, and to lay a wreath in what is only a small gesture in gratitude for the sacrices our service personnel made during the First World War. On this day, for them, we fall silent and remember."The First Minister will lay a wreath at the Stone of Remembrance at Edinburgh City Chambers before attending the service at St Giles Cathedral. Later in the day she is going to a special service at Glasgow Cathedral marking  years since the Armistice.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "Remembrance Sunday is an opportunity for people in Scotland to join with others across the world to commemorate those who made the ultimate sacrice in conflicts during the last century."It allows us a chance to honour the memory of those who gave their lives, while also paying tribute to our veterans and those who continue to serve today.ldquoThis year of course has added poignancy as it marks  years since the signing of the Armistice that ended the First World War."The laying of a wreath is a small but signicant tribute, and I am privileged to be able to do so on behalf of the people of Scotland."For the first time, a German leader will lay a wreath at the Cenotaph in London, with President Frank-Walter Steinmeier performing the duty on behalf of his nation in a historic act of reconciliation.Families whose ancestors died or were injured in the First World War will be remembering their relatives as they take part in a ldquopeoples procession".A total of , people, chosen by ballot, will have the opportunity to pay their respects to all those who served in the First World War by taking part in the Nations Thank You procession past the Cenotaph.Church bells will ring out today as they did at the end of the First World War ndash and a Westminster Abbey service will be held along with others in Glasgow, Cardf and Belfast, to give thanks for peace and those who ed.This afternoon a concert will take place at Edinburgh Napier Universitys Craiglockhart Campus, the site of a former military hospital for shell-shocked officers during the Great War. It will include musical performances from George Watsons College Symphony Orchestra and Scottish fiddlers.Meanwhile, director Danny Boyle is asking people to gather on beaches across the UK on November  and etch silhouettes in the sand "remembering the millions of lives lost or changed forever by the conflict".Events will take place at low tide at a number of beaches, including St Ninians beach in Shetland, Perranporth in Cornwall and Clacton-on-Sea in Essex.Battles Over ndash a series of hundreds of local events to mark the centenary of the Armistice ndash will also be held across the country today.Pipers will play, beacons will be lit, and church bells will ring in all corners of the UK and around the world as communities pay tribute to the First World War fallen.Silhouettes of soldiers from the First World War have also been projected on to famous UK landmarks, including Edinburgh Castle, the Marble Arch and Titanic Belfast.The silhouettes have appeared all over the UK since the campaign launched in February, commemorating the British and Commonwealth troops who died in the First World War while also raising funds for military charities.One of the largest overseas gatherings to mark Armistice Day will be in France, where president Emmanuel Macron will host German chancellor Angela Merkel and dignitaries from  countries.Americans will remember those who fought alongside French and British Empire troops on the Western Front from  onwards with a ceremony in the National Cathedral in Washington. Events will also be held in Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.Munich hosted a European Requiem ndash music from across the continent ndash on Saturday. Today, in Karlsruhe, there will be an ecumenical church service, with visitors from Coventry attending.Later this month, Germans mark their own sombre commemoration of the victims of all conflict and oppression, Volkstrauertag. Old soldiers and others wear a blue cornflower to remember those who lost their lives.

title: armistice-100-nicola-sturgeon-lays-wreath-in-edinburgh
story: Thousands of people across the country observed a two-minute silence at am in recognition of the centenary of the Armistice and those who lost their lives during the war.Many did so as they attended ceremonies, parades and services, others pausing for reflection in locations such as railway stations - echoing acts of remembrance taking place across the UK on this day of commemmorations globally.She did so after  rounds were fired from Edinburgh Castle, with the guns then falling silent.Of the , Scots who joined the forces, more than , died during the First World War.Nearly every
